content: The "Violent Crime Reduction Act of 2007" designates and provides assistance for high-intensity interstate gang activity areas under Title XV of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994. The "Violent Crime Reduction Act of 2007" defines key terms such as Governor, high-intensity interstate gang activity area, and State. The Attorney General can designate specified areas as high-intensity interstate gang activity areas based on certain criteria. Federal assistance is available for these designated areas. The "Violent Crime Reduction Act of 2007" allows the Attorney General to designate high-intensity interstate gang activity areas for federal assistance. This includes establishing criminal street gang enforcement teams with federal, state, and local law enforcement authorities for coordinated investigation and prosecution of criminal street gangs and offenders. Personnel can be reassigned or detailed from federal departments or agencies to support these teams. The "Violent Crime Reduction Act of 2007" authorizes the Attorney General to designate high-intensity interstate gang activity areas for federal assistance. This involves creating criminal street gang enforcement teams with personnel reassigned from federal departments to support investigations and prosecutions. Each team consists of agents and officers from the FBI. Funding is provided for team operations and national/regional meetings to enhance effectiveness through intelligence sharing and best practices. Teams established for criminal street gang enforcement consist of agents and officers from various federal agencies, state and local law enforcement, and prosecutors. The Attorney General considers gang crime levels and violent crime extent when designating high-intensity interstate gang activity areas. The Attorney General considers current and predicted gang crime levels, the relationship between violent crime and gang activity, resources committed by law enforcement agencies, potential impact of increased federal resources, and any other relevant criteria when designating high-intensity interstate gang activity areas. The Attorney General may allocate Federal resources to enhance local response to gang crime activities in designated areas. Up to 94 additional Assistant U.S. Attorneys can be hired to address high-intensity interstate gang activity, with necessary appropriations authorized. SEC. 3. Grants to state and local prosecutors to combat violent crime and protect witnesses and victims of crimes. The Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 is amended to allow hiring additional prosecutors, funding technology and training for accurate identification of gang members and violent offenders, and prosecuting young violent offenders. Authorization of appropriations is also amended. The Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 is amended to authorize $20,000,000 for fiscal years 2008 through 2012. Grants are provided to establish state-wide crime prevention databases to track criminals, arrests, prosecutions, and convictions. The Office of Justice Programs will award grants to State and local programs for this purpose.
